awd_titl_txt: Three-Dimensional Characterization and Simulation of Deformation in Hexagonal Metals
awd_abstract_narration:
Many lightweight metals such as magnesium, titanium, and zirconium alloys have a hexagonal crystal structure, which is unique from the cubic structures of commonly used aluminum and steel alloys. The room-temperature deformation of hexagonal metals is often dominated by a process known as mechanical twinning, wherein atoms shift positions to a highly symmetric arrangement in order to accommodate an applied stress or load. How mechanical twinning operates in such commercially-relevant, structurally-loaded, hexagonal metals is presently not fully understood and, therefore, limits the computational design of such materials and their manufacturing processes. An improved understanding can accelerate their development, reduce associated costs, and provide enhanced reliability of manufactured components. This award supports research towards the understanding of deformation of these technologically important materials, which have application in lightweight automotive and aerospace components, as well as many other structural applications where high strength and low weight are critical.

At the fundamental level, the controlling factor in the mechanical behavior of structural metals is the resistance of the crystal lattice to motion of dislocations, formation of mechanical twins, and displacive phase transformations. Particularly in hexagonal metals and alloys (Mg, Ti, Zr), which lack easily activated dislocation slip systems, mechanical twinning is prominent to accommodate plastic deformation. In this research program, the evolving twin structure in such metals is comprehensively characterized in three dimensions (3D) to gain novel insights and interpretations on the formation and propagation of twins and their relation to, for instance, parent grain orientation or grain boundary character distribution. The data will be used to validate constitutive descriptions of twin formation by incorporating the 3D microstructural information into full-field crystal plasticity simulations at high spatial resolution. Thus, this work provides a more complete understanding of how twins form and can fill in the presently missing knowledge to more confidently model the contribution of mechanical twinning to plastic deformation.

por.por_cntn:
Lightweight metallic materials such as titanium or magnesium are promising candidates for a number of structural applications, but they exhibit specific internal responses to permanent (plastic) deformation that are different from, and more complex than, other structural metals such as steels or aluminum. Properly understanding and modeling this behavior, termed "mechanical twinning", is a current challenge in materials science. The intended intellectual merit of this project was to complement the body of existing surface measurements of mechanical twinning activity with a three-dimensional characterization of twin structure evolution in plastically-strained hexagonal polycrystals (here a Mg alloy) and to rationalize the observed locations of and relations among mechanical twins with a corresponding crystal plasticity simulation of the observed volume. While this goal has not been fully reached, the two most significant impacts of the project on the development of the field are improvements in methodologies used in simulating and characterizing grain-scale deformation of crystalline materials, e.g. metals.

The first improvement enables the use of a numerically very efficient grid-based solution strategy for (crystal) mechanics, which has recently gained much traction in the community, to be applied to geometries that are not strictly bulk-periodic, such as situations involving internal or external surfaces. Since one of the goals of the project was to better understand the correlation between local stress state and mechanical twin formation, means to simulate the surface and near-surface volumes of characterized deformation samples are required. Efficient spectral method solvers are attractive in this regard as they allow for calculations at sufficiently high spatial resolution, but require strictly periodic boundary conditions on the domain of interest. The constitutive material description enabling free surfaces despite a periodic solution has been incorporated into the open-source D?sseldorf Advanced Material Simulation Kit and is freely available to the materials research community.

The second substantial improvement concerns the non-destructive measurement of local crystal orientation (and lattice strain) using Differential Aperture X-ray Microscopy (DAXM). This technique is, so far solely, available at the Advanced Photon Source (Argonne National Lab) and vital for probing the response of crystalline matter to plastic deformation resulting in critical information to develop accurate models of crystal plasticity. This characterization method depends on the identification of multiple diffraction peak locations on a detector image. We were able to devise a novel strategy to detect (sometimes many) more of the fainter signals, resulting in a larger number of reliable data points within the characterized material volume. Such higher-quality datasets are beneficial not only for the reconstruction of the mechanical twin network targeted in this project, but also in other studies that rely on the unique advanteges offered by DAXM.

Our outreach activities have targeted instructing K-12 students about materials science and engineering through an outreach activity termed "Scanning Electron Microscopy Education" (SEMED). The overall goal is to spur on students' interests in a potential career in science and/or engineering. Feedback from participants showed that teachers and students appreciated the program and would like to come back again in future years. We have collected data that shows that some of the K-12 students who participated were stimulated by the program and have thought of studying science, engineering, and/or math in college.  Overall, the SEMED program impacted over 300 K-12 students and their teachers during the duration of this award.

One graduate student and one postdoctoral research assistant have been supported through this award. Training of students and postdocs in research involving experimental and simulation/modeling approaches is an enabling capability for identified national goals of the Integrated Computational Materials Engineering (ICME) thrust. The students involved in the project improved their skills in particular with respect to the use of deformation testing equipment, computer-aided data analytics and visualization, programming, and crystal plasticity simulation.
